text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Finland's top 40 companies expected to pay a record seven billion markka in dividends for last year despite a fall in profits compared to 1995.

- Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen says Finland will not be taken by force into a European military alliance, commenting in Rome on a Dutch proposal to merge the European Union with the Western European Union. @
- Managing director of folded firm fired by the bankruptcy estate while on maternity leave was not subject to discrimination, Supreme Court rules.
- State subsidies and fear of mildew has encouraged house repair and hundreds of projects are starting to renew roofs, facades or balconies in the capital area alone.
- Transport ministry preparing new law to govern electronic media.
- Confederation of Industry and Employers (TT) planning ways to measure employees' know-how which could eventually be used as an item in balance sheets. @
- Popularity of German language in Finnish high schools is falling while French, Russian and Latin are gaining.
- Russian tourism to Finland up 40 percent year-on-year early 1997 measured by hotel bookings.
- Non-life insurers' profitability the best in 15 years, 1996 reports show. @
KAUPPALEHTI

- Yhtyneet Kuvalehdet -- jointly owned by WSOY and Otava -- may up its stake in MTV to 15 percent this week, managing director says. The deal would make it the second largest owner of the commercial television channel after Aamulehti.
- Yrjo Niskanen, chairman of UPM-Kymmene's board, returned to Nokia's board after just one year of absence.
- Wholesaler Onninen says is not planning a listing now. @
AAMULEHTI
- Finns expected to be celebrating Easter in heavy snow storm.
- Russian tourism to Finland has increased rapidly and may soon outstrip current train and aircraft capactiy, estimates show.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Spoken fluency in foreign languages is more important in daily life than proficient writing, study shows. @
DEMARI
- Finland should establish a mission in Brussels dedicated only to NATO affairs, Defence Minister Anneli Taina says.
HUFVUDSTADSBLADET
- Unsuitable for unmarried priest to live with her partner, says Bishop Erik Viktstrom.
- Using ecological farming on all Finland's arable land would improve employment by one percentage point, study shows.
